0.text: Social phobia, or social anxiety disorder, is characterized by intense anxiety in social interaction situations. Asking for help is one of the common situations that cause anxiety in people with this disorder.
0.fact: Charles Darwin, a famous naturalist and author of the theory of evolution, suffered from severe social phobia. He avoided public speaking and often experienced panic attacks before having to interact with people, despite his outstanding achievements.

1.text: Glossophobia is the fear of public speaking, one of the most common forms of social phobia. About 75% of people experience some degree of fear before speaking in public.
1.fact: According to a survey by the American Psychological Association, about 30% of Americans experience a strong fear of public speaking, making it one of the most common fears.

2.text: One of the key aspects of social phobia is the fear of social interactions with strangers. This can manifest as avoiding contacts, striving to be unnoticed, and feeling awkward or anxious.
2.fact: Franz Kafka, a famous writer, suffered from severe social phobia and often had difficulties interacting with strangers. His works, such as 'The Trial' and 'The Castle,' reflect his deep fears and anxieties.

3.text: People with social phobia often avoid phone calls and video conferences due to the fear of being misunderstood or making a bad impression. They may worry about how their voice sounds or what they will say.
3.fact: One way to reduce anxiety before phone calls is practice and preparation. Making a list of questions and answers before the call can help a person feel more confident and reduce fear.

4.text: Social phobia can lead people to avoid socializing outside of mandatory situations (such as work or school) to avoid potentially anxiety-provoking social interactions.
4.fact: Research shows that about 15 million Americans (approximately 7% of the US population) suffer from social phobia, and a significant portion of them prefer to avoid social situations outside their mandatory roles.

5.text: Entering a crowded room can be especially anxiety-inducing for people with social phobia due to the fear of being the center of attention. They may worry about being watched or judged.
5.fact: Albert Einstein, a great physicist, suffered from severe social phobia and avoided large gatherings. He preferred to work alone and communicate only with close friends and colleagues.

6.text: People with social phobia can be very sensitive to criticism, especially on social media, where it is public and can be seen by many people.
6.fact: Digital detox is becoming increasingly popular. Many people, including celebrities, temporarily disconnect from social media to restore their mental health and reduce the impact of negative criticism.

7.text: Silence can be a way to avoid negative attention and potential criticism, but it can also limit their career growth and professional opportunities.
7.fact: Active listening techniques can help people feel more confident in meetings. For example, focusing on listening and preparing questions or comments in advance can help reduce anxiety and improve participation in discussions.

8.text: Social phobia is characterized by intense anxiety in situations where a person may be evaluated by others. One such situation is being asked to give their opinion in front of a group. This can cause fear of making a mistake or being negatively evaluated.

9.text: People with social phobia may feel significant anxiety and discomfort in places with large crowds, such as the subway. Such places can induce fear of being noticed, judged, or encountering unexpected social situations.
9.fact: Adele, a famous British singer, suffers from social phobia and panic attacks. She avoids crowded places like the subway to reduce the risk of panic symptoms.

10.text: People with social phobia often try to avoid being the center of attention to avoid attracting unnecessary interest and evaluation from others. They may fear criticism or ridicule, which increases the desire to stay in the background.

11.text: According to the National Institute of Mental Health in the USA, about 12.1% of the population experience social anxiety disorder at some point in their lives, often leading to avoidance of public places.

12.text: Research shows that moderate levels of anxiety can actually improve performance by activating the sympathetic nervous system and increasing concentration. This phenomenon is known as the Yerkes-Dodson law.

13.text: Anxiety before social interaction is known as 'social anxiety' and can range from mild discomfort to severe fear. It is the third most common mental disorder after depression and alcoholism.

14.text: Fear of authority figures is called 'hierophobia.' This is not an official medical term, but it is often used to describe excessive anxiety when interacting with people in higher positions.
14.fact: Warren Buffett, one of the most successful investors in the world, experienced strong fear of public speaking and communication with authority figures in his youth. He even enrolled in a course to overcome this fear, which later significantly helped his career.

15.text: Fear of going to shopping centers can be associated with agoraphobia - the fear of open spaces or places where it is difficult to quickly find an exit. However, it can also be a manifestation of social phobia or ochlophobia (fear of crowds).

16.text: Psychologists call the fear of the unknown 'intolerance of uncertainty.' This condition can affect not only social situations but also decision-making in general.

17.text: Fear of performing in front of an unfamiliar audience is called 'social evaluative anxiety.' It is a combination of fear of negative evaluation and fear of new situations.
17.fact: Emma Stone, an Oscar-winning actress, openly spoke about her struggle with panic attacks, especially in situations involving performances in front of new audiences. She used therapy and breathing techniques to cope with this.

18.text: Fear of phone calls is called 'telephobia.' This phenomenon is becoming more common in the digital communication era, where people are accustomed to text communication.
18.fact: A study conducted by BankMyCell in 2019 found that 76% of millennials experience anxiety when they need to make a phone call. Among Generation Z, this figure is even higher - 81%.

19.text: Anxiety when returning goods can be associated with fear of conflict, fear of negative evaluation, or a sense of guilt for 'causing inconvenience' to store staff.
19.fact: Anxiety when returning goods is often associated with the broader phenomenon known as 'assertophobia' - the fear of asserting one's rights or expressing one's needs.

20.text: Fear of unprepared performances is often associated with 'imposter syndrome' - the feeling that you are not competent enough and may be 'exposed.'
20.fact: The technique of 'improvisational thinking' can be helpful. Instead of panicking due to lack of preparation, try to perceive the situation as an opportunity for spontaneous and sincere communication with the audience.

21.text: Fear of writing or making notes in the presence of others is sometimes called 'scriptophobia.' It is a specific case of social anxiety related to the fear of being evaluated by others.
21.fact: There is no exact data on the prevalence of this fear, but a study published in the Journal of Anxiety Disorders showed that about 7% of people experience significant discomfort when they need to write in the presence of others.

22.text: Difficulties in saying 'no,' especially to persistent people, are called 'pleaser syndrome' or 'people-pleasing disorder' by psychologists. This is associated with the desire to avoid conflict and fear of negative evaluation.
22.fact: A study conducted by the University of Pennsylvania found that about 68% of people experience discomfort when they need to say 'no' in sales situations.

23.text: Martin Luther King Jr., a famous civil rights activist, experienced strong anxiety when expressing his opinion in front of groups at the beginning of his career. However, by overcoming his fears, he became one of the most influential speakers and leaders of the civil rights movement.

24.text: People with social phobia may experience significant anxiety and stress when receiving unexpected invitations to weddings or other celebrations. Such events often involve interacting with many people and participating in social interactions, which can be particularly challenging for them.
24.fact: Daniel Radcliffe, known for his role as Harry Potter, suffers from social phobia and often avoids large public events. He prefers to spend time in small groups of friends and family.

25.text: People with social phobia often avoid phone conversations in the presence of others due to the fear of being heard and evaluated. They may worry about how their voice sounds, possible mistakes in their speech, or that their conversation will cause a negative reaction from others.

26.text: Avoiding parties can be associated with 'protective behavior' - a strategy that reduces anxiety in the short term but can increase social isolation and fear in the long term.

27.text: According to studies, about 7-9% of people suffer from paruresis, also known as shy bladder syndrome, which makes them avoid using public restrooms.

28.text: People with social phobia may experience significant anxiety when receiving proposals to meet or go on a date. The main reasons include fear of negative evaluation, lack of self-confidence, and concern about possible mistakes in communication.

29.text: Fear of phone calls, especially from unknown numbers, can be caused by worry about not knowing how to respond correctly, or that the conversation may not go as expected. This can include fear of possible confrontation or the need to quickly respond to unexpected questions.

30.text: People with social phobia may experience significant anxiety when interacting with strangers during travel or vacation. They may fear negative evaluation, doing something inappropriate, or not knowing how to maintain the conversation.

31.text: Studies show that about 60% of people with social anxiety experience discomfort during eye contact. This can be one of the most anxiety-inducing aspects of social interactions.

32.text: People with social phobia may experience significant anxiety at the possibility of conflicts or arguments with strangers. They may fear negative evaluation, misunderstanding, or even aggressive reactions, leading to avoidance of any potentially conflictual situations.

33.text: According to studies, about 20-30% of people experience significant discomfort when being photographed, especially in groups. This anxiety can be associated with fear of negative evaluation and dissatisfaction with their appearance.

34.text: Isaac Newton, a great scientist, was also very reserved and avoided participating in public events and new groups. He preferred to spend time alone conducting scientific research.

35.text: Studies show that cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be very effective in treating social anxiety. CBT helps people change negative thoughts and develop a more positive attitude toward social interactions.

36.text: Anxiety before exams in practical skills and abilities is a common problem, especially among people with social phobia. The fear of being evaluated and the possibility of failure can increase stress and nervousness.
36.fact: Thomas Edison, a famous inventor, had difficulties with traditional methods of learning and exams. He preferred to learn through practical experiments and experiences, avoiding formal exams.

37.text: People with social phobia often experience significant anxiety when talking to others. Fear of negative evaluation, worry about how their words will be perceived, and fear of making a mistake can increase anxiety and nervousness.

38.text: People with social phobia often prefer to walk when there are few or no people outside. This helps them avoid social interactions that can cause anxiety and stress.
38.fact: Howard Hughes, a famous American businessman and aviator, known for his social phobia and numerous phobias, preferred solitary walks and avoided crowded places. He tried to remain unnoticed and avoid social interactions.

39.text: Eye contact activates mirror neurons, which can enhance feelings of empathy and understanding but also cause strong emotions. This can be one of the reasons why eye contact causes such anxiety.

normal.text: Your results show that you feel confident and comfortable in various social situations. You do not experience significant difficulties in interacting with strangers, speaking in front of an audience, or participating in group events. This indicates that you have either mild or no social phobia, allowing you to actively and freely participate in social life.
normal.title: No social phobia

mild.text: Your results show that you encounter some difficulties in social situations. You may feel insecure when interacting with strangers, speaking in front of an audience, or participating in large group events. This indicates that you have mild social phobia. However, with the right support and practice, you can improve your communication skills and feel more comfortable in social interactions.
mild.title: Mild social phobia

moderate.text: Your results indicate significant difficulties you experience in social situations. You may feel very insecure and anxious when interacting with strangers, speaking in front of an audience, or participating in group events. This indicates a severe form of social phobia. It is important to remember that you can cope with this situation by seeking professional help and support. With the right approach and therapy, you can gradually overcome these difficulties and improve your quality of life.
moderate.title: Severe social phobia

text: Have you ever wondered how comfortable you feel in social situations? Do you experience anxiety when you need to talk to a stranger or speak in front of an audience? Our test will help you understand how pronounced your signs of social phobia are.

The test consists of questions covering various aspects of social interaction, from talking to colleagues to participating in public events. By answering them, you can better understand your feelings and reactions in different situations.
